source.document_id: Understanding the economic impact of introducing a new procedure

metadata.title: Understanding the Economic Impact of Introducing a New Procedure: Calculating Downstream Revenue of Endobronchial Ultrasound With Transbronchial Needle Aspiration as a Model

sections.abstract: Over the last decade, endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) evolved into a validated and powerful diagnostic tool. Although it is integral to medical care in some health-care systems, others struggle to justify its purchase based on diminishing reimbursement. In analyzing its value to a health-care system, looking at procedural reimbursement alone will grossly underestimate its economic impact. Downstream revenue has been defined by administrators as revenue captured after patients use one hospital service and then use others. By analyzing consecutive EBUS cases and taking downstream revenue into account, 2400000 in collections was attributed to 97 patients who were newly referred for this procedure.
sections.methods: Retrospective review of 200 consecutive EBUS-TBNA procedures performed at the Medical University of South Carolina between 2008 and 2009 (start date June 30, 2008). Patients were classified as established patients (EPs) or new patients (NPs) to the health-care system within 30 days of EBUS-TBNA. NPs were subdivided into new patient brief interaction (NPBI: <6 visits, no hospitalizations) and new patient continued care (NPCC). For NPs, collections (professional and technical) were obtained for services from 30 days prior to 180 days after the index procedure, restricted to services directly related to the EBUS-TBNA referral and subsequent diagnosis/treatment. For EPs, downstream services directly related to the EBUS-TBNA within 180 days were counted; collections were not calculated. Data abstracted included radiologic studies, consults, pathology, hospitalizations, procedures, and treatments.
sections.results: Of 200 patients, 97 were EPs and 103 were NPs (59 NPBI, 44 NPCC). Lung cancer was present in 49% overall and metastatic cancer in 7%. Among NPs in the 30 days prior to EBUS-TBNA, there were 30 radiologic studies, 94 consults, and 28 procedures. Post-procedure encounters (within 180 days) included, for NPBI/NPCC/EP respectively: radiologic studies 22/275/305; consults 88/459/470; hospitalizations 0/33/31; procedures 14/44/61; radiation therapy 0/240/310; chemotherapy 0/88/88. The hospital collections attributable to NPs were 2400000, including 1970000 in technical fees and 440000 in professional fees. Private insurance accounted for 31% of payer mix. Approximately 43% of NPs (44/103) remained in-system for continued care (NPCC).

population.text: Patients undergoing EBUS-TBNA at a single academic medical center (MUSC) during 2008-2009, including both established patients and patients newly referred to the system.
inclusion_criteria: Underwent EBUS-TBNA at MUSC during the study window
For NPs: referral from non-MUSC-affiliated physicians within 30 days of index procedure
exclusion_criteria: None explicitly stated; all consecutive EBUS-TBNA cases in the period were reviewed

intervention.text: Introduction and use of EBUS-TBNA service
intervention.details: Procedures performed with Olympus BF-UC160F-OL8 bronchoscope, NA-201SX-4022 single-use needles, and EU-C60 ultrasound processor; downstream services within 30 days prior to and 180 days after the procedure were tracked for NPs.

comparison.details: Encounter patterns compared between NP continued care (NPCC) and established patients (EPs); NP brief interaction (NPBI) summarized separately.

domains.name: Confounding
domains.support_for_judgment: No control for confounding; descriptive, non-comparative financial analysis.

domains.name: Selection of participants
domains.support_for_judgment: Consecutive cases at a single center; classification into NP/EP could introduce selection differences.

domains.name: Classification of interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Clear operational definitions for NP, NPBI, NPCC, and EP categories.

domains.name: Deviations from intended interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Observational financial analysis; no protocolized interventions beyond standard care.

domains.name: Missing data
domains.support_for_judgment: Extent of missing billing/collections data not reported.

domains.name: Measurement of outcomes
domains.support_for_judgment: Collections obtained from hospital billing systems; potential misclassification of relatedness to index procedure.

domains.name: Selection of the reported result
domains.support_for_judgment: Primary focus on NPs; EP financial data not reported; window limited to 180 days.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In 200 consecutive EBUS-TBNA cases, 103 new patients generated 2400000 in downstream collections (1970000 technical; 440000 professional), with 44/103 (43%) retained for continued care.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Demonstrates that evaluating downstream revenue can justify capital investment in EBUS-TBNA despite limited direct procedural reimbursement.
